results.headline: Review: In ‘Maudie,’ a Painter Spins Beauty From Despair
results.summary_short: Sally Hawkins and Ethan Hawke open up two closed people, unleashing torrents of feeling, in this film inspired by the life of a self-taught artist.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Maudie

results.headline: Review: From Vittorio De Sica, the Comic Anxieties of la Dolce Vita
results.summary_short: “Il Boom,” starring Alberto Sordi as a building contractor with a lavish lifestyle, is a 1963 comedy that is only now getting an American release.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Boom

results.headline: Review: ‘Score: A Film Music Documentary’ Gives Composers Their Due
results.summary_short: The likes of Max Steiner, Ennio Morricone and Bernard Herrmann are hailed in Matt Schrader’s film, as well as John Williams, Hans Zimmer and others.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Score: A Film Music Documentary

results.headline: Review: In ‘Harmonium,’ a Family Lets the Wrong One In
results.summary_short: A mysterious man becomes a disruptive presence for a married couple and their daughter in Koji Fukada’s well-acted family drama.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Harmonium

results.headline: Review: ‘All Eyez on Me’ Is Uninspired. Tupac Shakur Was Anything But.
results.summary_short: Benny Boom’s film fails the considerable talent of the complex rapper it chronicles and the actor portraying him, Demetrius Shipp Jr.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of All Eyez on Me

results.headline: Review: In ‘The Book of Henry,’ a Little Child Shall, Well, You Know
results.summary_short: Naomi Watts stars in a cliché-stuffed dumb movie about a smart kid, directed by Colin Trevorrow (“Jurassic World”).

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Book of Henry

results.headline: Review: ‘F(l)ag Football’ Finds Gay Athletes Upending Stereotypes
results.summary_short: The documentary, directed by Seth Greenleaf, follows teams in the National Gay Flag Football League as they prepare for the championship game.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of F(l)ag Football

results.headline: Review: ‘47 Meters Down,’ With Great Whites Circling Above
results.summary_short: Mandy Moore and Claire Holt play sisters looking for adventures in Mexico, but being stuck in a cage on the ocean floor wasn’t what they had in mind.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 47 Meters Down

results.headline: Review: ‘Hearing Is Believing’ Documents a Rare Talent
results.summary_short: The documentary chronicles the musical development of Rachel Flowers, a blind musician and composer, but it would have benefited from more depth and context.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hearing Is Believing

results.headline: Review: Car-Pooling to End Ireland’s Troubles in ‘The Journey’
results.summary_short: Nick Hamm’s drama imagines a fictional drive shared by the Irish republican leader Martin McGuinness and the Unionist Ian Paisley.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Journey

results.headline: Review: Alternative Energy Strikes Back in ‘Kill Switch’
results.summary_short: Dan Stevens contends with drones, militants and a video-game-style parallel universe in his quest to save humanity in this sci-fi feature.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kill Switch

results.headline: Review: Finding Love (and Slapstick) While ‘Lost in Paris’
results.summary_short: The filmmakers Fiona Gordon and Dominique Abel star in their fourth movie, a tale infused with physical comedy about a woman in search of her aunt.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lost in Paris

results.headline: Review: In ‘Rough Night,’ It’s Women Behaving Badly (Yawn)
results.summary_short: Scarlett Johansson and Kate McKinnon play old friends whose boozy bachelorette weekend goes very, very wrong in a comedy from Lucia Aniello.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rough Night

results.display_title: Once Upon a Time in Venice
results.headline: Review: ‘Once Upon a Time in Venice’ Unleashes a Bland Bruce Willis
results.summary_short: A private detective is desperate to recover his stolen dog in this action-comedy from Mark and Robb Cullen.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Once Upon a Time in Venice

results.headline: Review: In ‘Cars 3,’ Lightning McQueen Faces an Existential Crisis
results.summary_short: Lightning is back and feeling a bit old in this latest breezy feature in the Pixar franchise. It offers life lessons that will resonate with adults as well as with children.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cars 3

results.headline: Review: A Grieving Mother Seeks Her Own Justice in ‘Moka’
results.summary_short: Frédéric Mermoud’s slow-burn revenge thriller and character drama is a first-rate showcase for the actresses Emmanuelle Devos and Nathalie Baye.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Moka

results.headline: Review: In ‘Megan Leavey,’ a Marine, Her Dog and a Bond Forged in War
results.summary_short: Based on a true story, this film, starring Kate Mara, is both harrowing and heartstring-tugging.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Megan Leavey

results.headline: Review: For an Aging Actor, Another Chance to Be ‘The Hero’
results.summary_short: Brett Haley’s low-key feature, about an older actor seeking redemption after being reduced to a cliché, belongs to its star, Sam Elliott.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Hero

results.headline: Review: In ‘Dawson City: Frozen Time,’ Early Movies Lost and Found
results.summary_short: A lot of future moguls got their start in one remote Yukon town. And an amazing amount of film history was left behind.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dawson City: Frozen Time

results.headline: Review: Mom, Dad, the Kid and the Dog. What Could Be Scarier?
results.summary_short: “It Comes at Night,” the sophomore feature of Trey Edward Shults, is as spookily self-assured and ambitious as “Krisha.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of It Comes at Night
